WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


ENTERTAINMENT

Every Taylor Sheridan Show, Ranked: A Skeptic and a Believer Debate the Best and Worst
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-11-27 19:00:00

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. The best Taylor Sheridan shows have accumulated their loyal, and large, followings for fairly obvious reasons: They're just damn good. The 55-year-old actor turned writer-producer knows how to write compelling characters and play them off each other in distinctive settings. And he has a knack for channeling and showing off star power, whether it's Sylvester Stallone in “Tulsa King,” Harrison Ford and Helen Mirren in “1923,” or Billy Bob Thornton in “Landman.” But stretching his empire into eight series has resulted in a feeling that Sheridan has spread himself a little too thin as a writer, and more recent seasons of his shows have shown the signs of a creator pulled in a few too many directions. Notorious for flying solo and exerting tremendous control over his projects, Sheridan's said he's usually on set during the week and then writes an entire episode of one of his shows on Saturdays — all fueled by regular B-12 shots, of course. Sheridan might do well to value quality over quantity a bit more, and perhaps, with the shrinkage of the streaming ecosystem and his departure from Paramount for NBCUniversal, he'll have an opportunity to reset. Ranking Taylor Sheridan's shows is not massively difficult because there are some that clearly stand out and others that sink to the bottom. Though exactly which is which is up for some debate, so that's exactly what we've done. IndieWire Digital Director Christian Blauvelt is an admirer of Sheridan and appreciative of his work. He thinks it's impressive what an actor who had a bit part in “Star Trek: Enterprise” and played a villain on “Veronica Mars” has achieved as a creator, while mostly maintaining a respectable level of quality. Head TV Critic Ben Travers is more of a skeptic — he certainly doesn't agree that Sheridan's success stems from great writing (great casting seems more likely, plus a convenient dearth of prestige-flavored westerns) — and he's only found one or two of Sheridan's shows worthy of weekly viewing. Who's right? Who's wrong? And what shows are worth your time? We'll let you decide. IndieWire's list of Taylor Sheridan's shows, ranked from best to worst, is below. Ben Travers: Not to overextend whatever credit I have as our resident “hater,” but “Tulsa King” is my preferred Taylor Sheridan show because it's the least like all of Taylor Sheridan's other shows. The first season is funny! The episodes hum! The main characters actually like each other! “Tulsa King” is about a rag-tag group of outcasts who try to build something together, rather than a haunted family who fights all the time as their long-sullied legacy falls apart. Which one of those options sounds better to you? For Sheridan, it's not “Tulsa King.” Despite sky-high viewership, the creator (whose work on the series ended when he co-wrote the pilot) wasn't pleased with the first season and tried to oust the showrunner, Terence Winter (“Boardwalk Empire”). Thankfully, Winter made his way back to the fray (off and on), and “Tulsa King” was able to preserve parts of its original tone, while still getting Sylvester Stallone's hands dirty enough to fit in with Sheridan's other tough guys. Is it perfect? No. It's far from the best of either writer (Winter or Stallone), and there's certainly a more serious crime drama stirring somewhere within this silly one. But when so many of Sheridan's shows feel like medieval torture chambers (misery, violence, more misery), I'm going to savor whatever time I can get with a kingly court jester. Christian Blauvelt: The turn away from miserabilism that “Tulsa King” represents for Sheridan is a welcome one, though I can't help think that this “crime comedy” series gets a little too silly for its own good on many occasions. And I wonder how much it would hold together at all if not for the star power of Stallone at its center. I also think that the show gets better once Sheridan left: I found the early part of Season 1 to be kind of a tract-in-show-form where Sheridan could spew his anti-woke sentiments without necessarily giving them much dramatic structure. It was annoying. I found those early eps to be as performatively about the “culture wars” as anything Sheridan has ever done, and given an added degree of inauthenticity because it feels at times that he's really a lefty just dressed in MAGA clothing. Similarly, I found that some of the culture warrior things he said on “The Joe Rogan Experience” ended up verbatim in “Lioness” Season 2. More on that in the “Lioness” blurb, but yes, this is where I can acknowledge that I was so high on the Sheridan-verse I literally listened to his entire three-hour-plus Joe Rogan podcast, which was another reminder about what a terrible interviewer Rogan is and a massive missed opportunity given how few interviews Sheridan grants. Anyway, once “Tulsa King” actually became a show about its characters rather than making a point to ruffle PC sensibilities it became the fun romp you describe. Is it churlish to say that Sheridan's best show is one he barely had involvement with after its beginning? Of course. But though we are not here to bury Sheridan, we can certainly be clear-eyed about the limitations of his work as well. Christian: I mean, if any series brings tears to my eyes for the entire final episode that has to be a massive success, and for me “1883” is in every sense Sheridan's most perfectly formed show. This is the rare 10-episode series that actually does feel like a 10-hour movie, one devoid of flab and filler but that also never puts plot before character even as it's exquisitely plotted. A wagon-train Western for the ages, “1883” gives us our chronological first glimpse of the Dutton family as an impoverished first-generation Irish clan in Tennessee heading to parts West for a better life. Yes, it focuses on the trip's grind and misery, but not for the sake of miserabilism; more to establish real stakes, meaning, and purpose. It takes five episodes just for the wagon train to get out of Texas, and though that may be partly due to Sheridan being able to film that much more on his Texas ranch, it emphasizes what those seeking a better life in the West were willing to endure – largely on foot. And like any immigrant story, there's something incredibly hopeful at its core — a hope that justifies the grind. This is also one of the only Westerns other than “Heaven's Gate” to delve deep into the extraordinary diversity of those heading West — that they were very often immigrants from Germany, Sweden, Poland, the Balkans, and all over Eastern Europe, including persecuted Roma. Like “Heaven's Gate,” there isn't much English dialogue you hear from these characters and “1883” focuses on the misunderstandings that arise simply from the language barrier. Sheridan's writing of women can also be very bad across his work… and yet, he delivered the single most complex characterization of his entire writing career in Elsa (Isabel May), whose poetic narration anchors the series. There's also a reason why Sam Elliott got the most prominent acting award ever for a Sheridan show for his work on “1883” — a SAG Award for Best Actor in a Miniseries. As a classic Western gunslinger who suffers the loss of his entire family from smallpox before deciding to embark on one last journey to the Pacific as a wagon train boss, he ends up tugging at your heartstrings like no one else. Ben: Well, what you find poetic I find grating. Elsa's narration is a crutch, and her observations are too often vague platitudes that betray the insight she should have as a storyteller who knows the whole narrative. To that end, “1883” may acknowledge the American melting pot as it spills out across the plains, but its perspective remains rooted in a white family, which makes it familiar and limited. Women characters rank second only to Native Americans when it comes to Sheridan's vexing portrayals, and “1883” doesn't exactly work to acknowledge the ways in which the country's original settlers built a functioning society. That may not be fair to the story it does tell — with passion, earnestness, and ambition — but it's a historical fact that seems to butt against the writer's preferred American origin story. (And it makes his sadistic streak harder to stomach when the pioneers start dying off in disparate droves.) Elsewhere, James and Margaret Dutton (Tim McGraw and Faith Hill, respectively) don't do much for me as protagonists (or performers), which elevates Elliott's work almost by default. (I say almost because he is quite affecting, even if that SAG Award Actors Award should've gone to Steve Carell for “The Patient.”) Perhaps if “1883” weren't tied to “Yellowstone” — if it had been a true standalone project — some of these slights may have softened. But as it is, I still feel them. Christian: What's so invigorating about “1923” Season 1 is how much Sheridan works in pure adventure mode. It's not miserabilism for miserabilism's sake, even in the repeated, brutal beatings suffered by Aminah Nieves' Teonna, an Indigenous girl forced to live in an abusive Catholic boarding school. That misery has a point: to illuminate a particular injustice rarely shown before on American screens. And of course, it's all to set up a thrilling, cross-country revenge story for Teonna, which becomes the best part of Season 2 — maybe the only genuinely satisfying part of Season 2, when all is said and done. Yes, this show fizzles a bit by the end of its 16-episode run, and it's hard not to think that it would have been better served with less. But there's no storyline more purely fun and exciting in Sheridan's canon than that of big game hunter Spencer Dutton (Brandon Sklenar, in a breakout performance for the ages) finding romance with runaway British royal Alexandra (Julia Schlaepfer) on the East African savannah. Together, they're menaced by lions, sharks, and a consumptive tugboat captain trying to ferry them to Suez when Spencer gets the call to return to Montana lest his family empire be overrun by a mustache-twirling Timothy Dalton. Here, Sheridan thinks in terms of images for his storytelling in a way he doesn't always: When Spencer and Alexandra are adrift on the high seas following the aforementioned tugboat captain's death, they run afoul of an abandoned ocean liner “ghost ship” that causes them to wreck as well. A couple episodes later, after they're rescued, Alex runs afoul of the aristocrats who tried to force her into a loveless marriage and a shipboard duel with Spencer wearing a tux ensues. All of this is the kind of spectacle that even most big-screen entertainments haven't offered in years, and it's Sheridan making the absolute most of Paramount's budget-largesse at the time. The money is on the screen. Unfortunately, Season 2, with the exception of Teonna's revenge arc, does see Sheridan slipping back into his miserabilist tendencies. There's a godawful storyline where Dalton's land baron endlessly engages in sadomasochistic sex with two sex workers he's hired and is trying to turn against each other: Yes, it's trying to make a point about the entanglement of economic power and sexual abuse, but the point is established early and its continued elaboration calls into question Sheridan's own motives. There are still some great moments here and there — Spencer running afoul of evil hobos when hitching a ride on a boxcar and him freeing a tarred-and-feathered sex worker from a puritanical mob in Fort Worth come to mind — but the series ends on a note of such anguish that I can't ever imagine watching “1923” again. “1883” ends tragically but feels earned (rather than just it being “Oh, let's put our audience through as much agony as possible”). This show, however, hooks you with adventure and romance and a gripping revenge plot only to leave you totally shattered. Ben: You've done most of my hater work for me, Christian, so I'll just say Harrison Ford does a lot to make this grim western tolerable. In a rare cowboy role for the movie star, Ford's Jacob Dutton sports a perpetual grimace that's softened by our decades of affection for the actor himself. I don't know if I'd go as far as to say Sheridan relies on that endearing quality — he's going to tell his story, his way, no matter who's in the saddle — but it's certainly helpful to his audience. There's just something about that face, no matter what horrors it witnesses or perpetuates, that triggers your humanity. Ben: “Yellowstone” aside (kind of), Taylor Sheridan doesn't exactly have an established track record when it comes to creating sustainable TV series. That makes sense, to a degree, given he started in movies (and still often writes like he's making movies). But between “1883” (limited series), “Bass Reeves” (canceled after one season), and the relative infancy of his other “hit” shows, it's worth wondering whether any of his TV ideas are built to last. (Even “Tulsa King,” which is about to shoot its fourth season, has faced production issues every year! Season 4 doesn't even have a showrunner!) So the nicest thing I can say about “Mayor of Kingstown” is that it's proven it can go the distance. Relying on its star “Avenger” (if not a star “Avenger”) and a premiere episode twist straight out of “Game of Thrones,” the dark-and-gritty Michigan crime drama has produced four seasons in five years, all of which star Jeremy Renner's ex-con turned unofficial warden of a prison (Kings)town, Mike McLusky. Along the way, it's employed legends like Dianne Wiest and Edie Falco to bring emotional nuance to a series mired in merciless pain. It's antihero show in an age that's moved on from antiheroes, but hey, at least it's a legitimate show! Christian: It is an antihero show in an age of that's moved on from antiheroes — though I would argue that the Duttons in “Yellowstone” have basically become a crime family by that point, unlike their noble presentation in “1883” and “1923” — but the reason for that may also be that “Mayor of Kingstown” was the first series Sheridan wrote even though it wasn't the first to air. So it strangely has a whiff of the mid-2010s in many respects. I think this is peak middle-of-the-road Sheridan. Not particularly memorable, but, as you've said, oddly sustainable? This is probably the closest he comes to the CBS or TNT model of shows that people watch for years on end but that don't in any way move the culture. Ben: Ah, “Yellowstone.” The unexpected hit that became the backbone of an entire network (and then its streamer, and then, come 2029, another streamer). The Kevin Costner-starring Western certainly benefited from his star power, helping to lure an audience eager for the sweeping American grandeur captured in “Dances with Wolves” and the next iteration of iconic cowboys glimpsed in “Silverado,” “Wyatt Earp,” and “Open Range.” While Sheridan's breakthrough series certainly delivered on those fronts — John Dutton's existential battle against progress, time, and death itself proved to be the series' most arresting conflict, which was only emphasized by Sheridan's many, many, many montages of cowboys riding across the ranch's purple mountain majesty — the behind-the-scenes battles between “Yellowstone's” principal patriarchs ruined a delayed, extended, and ultimately nonsensical final season. And when I say “ruined,” I mean the best of “Yellowstone” fell to Earth alongside its omnipresent worst traits: uneven pacing, clichéd, redundant character development, and a brutal streak that made scenes too silly to take seriously and too nasty to savor. Even for those who thought parts of “Yellowstone” were worthy of the awards love that never came, the ending emphasized exactly why Sheridan's first TV series deserved exactly what it got: big ratings, little relevance. Christian: I do agree that the way “Yellowstone” ended was so disastrous it mars the entire show — to me it's far worse than what happened with the “Lost” or “Game of Thrones” finales, and there's part of me that thinks “Yellowstone” should be ranked last here as a result. Especially since “1883” and “1923” do so many more interesting things with this kind of material. “Yellowstone” is, above all, a ridiculous soap opera. That said, there are times throughout its run that you can see very clearly why it became such a phenomenon, and I think part of it is due to its pacing: This could be as languid a series as any on TV, one largely about character rather than plot (which is why the plot-heavy contortions of its final season are such a betrayal). This is a show where you suddenly could have Gil Birmingham giving a long monologue about the relationship between men and wolves, and how each exist to keep the population of the other in check — several minutes in, I let out an audible “This is great.” Same goes for the frequent musical performances (only Cheo Hodari Coker's “Luke Cage” in recent vintage embraced putting plot on the skids like this) and “hangout moments” with the cowboys in the bunk house. “Yellowstone” worked best when it was a mood, a vibe. Having Sheridan himself appear as a sex-god horse trader who counts Bella Hadid as his girlfriend actually contributed to that vibe. Having the endless mean-spiritedness of Jamie (Wes Bentley) and Beth (Kelly Reilly) curdle into conspiracy nonsense and an ultimate knife fight very much did not. Christian: I personally would rank “Lawmen: Bass Reeves” much higher on this list and I protest Ben's placement of it here! This is one of the most perceptive depictions in American media of that precise moment that Reconstruction transitioned into Jim Crow. And it did so via the first actual historical retelling of a real-life lawman in the Sheridan canon (though the series was created and showrun by Chad Sheehan). Bass Reeves was a real-life Black lawman who patrolled the Arkansas-Oklahoma border in the 1870s, and the exceptionally gifted David Oyelowo disappeared into this role as effectively as any actor in Sheridan's TV shows. The eight-part series tells an effective story about Reeves going from enslavement to the life of wearing a badge and building a family. It's overarching plot then concerns strange rumors of a “Mr. Sundown” who is spiriting away Black men accused of (often spurious) crimes, and Reeves' investigation has compelling implications for whether slavery ever fully went away or just became the culture of incarceration that's defined American judicial life ever since. The series is given some of the richest period specificity of any of Sheridan's shows via the extraordinary production design of “Do the Right Thing” and “Malcolm X” legend Wynn Thomas (who just received a richly deserved Honorary Oscar). Did “Bass Reeves” need Dennis Quaid as a wily foil for Reeves? Possibly not. But this is one of the more coherent and fully realized series on this list. Ben: I gotta say, you're making it sound a whole lot better than it looks. The premiere is a regurgitation of Bass Reeves' Wikipedia page, the legendary lawman's characterization is as broad and accessible as any stock cop on CBS, and the whole show only came to be because Sheridan thought he could fit Reeves into the “Yellowstone” universe, couldn't quite make it work, and then stuck his name on a seasonal anthology that only lasted one season. (They should really change the title from “Lawmen” to “Lawman,” but I guess they're holding out hope for a follow-up.) Like much of Sheridan's work, it may have good ideas and great production values, but it struggles with the core of great television: characters. I love Oyelowo, and he does his darnedest to liven up a rudimentary historic retelling, but his good-hearted lawman is too disengaged from the world around him. Everyone is too eager to agree with each other and get on with it, whether it's a man of faith conversing with an atheist or an old-school judge and a new-era officer. The series isn't interested in the nuanced internal conflicts that must have roiled inside a former slave who chose to protect and serve slave owners, a Black man forced to fight for the Confederate army, or even a pacifist who picked up a gun every single day. It's interested in tropes. And Bass deserves better. Christian: One of Sheridan's greatest skills is spotting rising talent to champion: Isabel May in “1883,” Brandon Sklenar in “1923,” and I'd argue Laysla de Oliveira in “Lioness.” The spectrum of material she's asked to play in Season 1 is extraordinary: Stuck in an abusive relationship and working as a fast-food fryer, de Oliveira's Cruz finds a way out when, during a fight with her hateful significant other, she literally stumbles into a Marine recruiting office. And she enlists. It puts her on a journey to becoming a covert operative in the CIA's Lioness division, where certain women agents go undercover in terrorist organizations, drug cartels, and more. Of Mexican and Syrian heritage, Cruz, who can speak Arabic, is perfect to go undercover inside an Al-Qaeda-style terrorist organization. She's to befriend the daughter of its leader, who, along with her father, leads a luxe life of designer apparel and luxury goods. So Cruz, coming from grinding poverty, has to act accustomed to that life in addition to achieving her mission objectives. I'm not sure there's an actor in any of these shows who's been asked to do more than de Oliveira. It all boils down to a remarkably critical take on U.S. adventurism abroad, down to the inspired choice of casting “Egyptian Jon Stewart” Bassem Youssef as the amiable terrorist leader. Nicole Kidman as a CIA operative with a disturbingly husky “American” accent does not lend sympathy to the U.S. cause, nor does Zoe Saldana as an operative almost pathologically capable of severing the brutality of her job from her cozy private life. Season 2 then goes in a similar direction, casting a critical eye on the U.S. drug war. It's all full of Sheridan indulgences, including him playing a devil-may-care Special Forces operative who can't keep his shirt on and spouts lines he spoke verbatim about “not being able to have a conversation” about trans issues on “The Joe Rogan Experience.” But working in an “action mode” suits Sheridan, especially as he doesn't indulge in jingoism. Ben: I'm not sure if I'm fully sold on “Lioness” as a critical take on America's international policy — for all the moral hesitancy over what their missions ultimately accomplish, there's still too much “rah rah” support for the military industrial complex to be seen as a full-on condemnation — but I have to say, as a pure narrative, I find it tremendously dull. The suspense is cheap, the characterizations are clichéd, and the action is hampered because — like way too many Sheridan shows — it's all so freaking dark! In the Season 1 finale, it takes more than 40 minutes to pull the pin on the grenade (so to speak), and once they do, the explosion can't even be seen through the black of night. That, and Nicole Kidman gets stuck with one of the worst line readings of her career, while Zoe Saldana barely survives her heated confrontation with the titular lioness. There's something to be said for men sitting and shouting at each other in rooms, stirring up trouble until it nearly starts a war, while the women do the real work outside in the field… but “Lioness” doesn't fit that feminist interpretation, as much as it wants you to believe it can. Ben: Before you even get into the ugliness within “Landman's” story, you have to first consider how fundamentally irresponsible it is, even as a piece of fiction. Here's a show so in love with the sound of its own ultra-conservative voice, not only is it happy to prop up the oil industry by spouting lies about clean energy, it's also happy to cash the checks Big Oil throws its way to keep spreading misinformation about why oilfields are the future and wind turbines are for weaklings. Which brings us to the nauseating nature of the narrative itself. A bitter, hardened story about a bitter, hardened oil lobbyist, the series is built on provocation. Tommy Norris (Billy Bob Thornton) loves to mock anyone and everyone he meets for knowing less than he does. That includes the many… uninformed women populating “Landman” (be it his impetuous ex-wife, his sexed-up daughter, or his “big city” attorney), as well as Tommy's white collar boss and any other authority figure who makes the mistake of knocking on his door. No one measures up to Tommy's standards, and he may like it that way, but it makes for an exhausting viewing experience — who wants to let some old, stuck-up asshole bullshit for hours on end, when he's so sure he knows better than everyone but remains completely oblivious that he's blabbing out of his ass? It's a testament to Thornton's tough-talking charms that “Landman” is still watchable, just as it's a black mark against Taylor Sheridan that he can't see the tragedy inherent to Tommy's story — a man trapped in the American dream as it rots beneath his feet. Instead, his creator only sees a hero, when by any objective measure, there only stands a fool. Christian: Sheridan has written some incredible women in these shows: Helen Mirren's Cara in “1923,” Laysla de Oliveira's Cruz in “Lioness,” Aminah Nieves' Teonna in “1923,” and Isabel May's Elsa in “1883” (the single most compelling character he's written, full-stop). Then there's “Landman.” Stephen Rodrick summed it up best in Rolling Stone when he asked of “Landman,” “Why does Jerry Jones have better lines than Demi Moore?” And that's even before considering the unfortunate writing for Ali Larter and Michelle Randolph's characters. Frankly, much of what I dislike about “Landman” is what similarly rubbed me the wrong way about those early eps of “Tulsa King”: You're right, Ben, that this series is “built on provocation.” It's almost like if Billy Bob Thornton's evil assassin character in the first season of “Fargo” was suddenly given a heroic reframing — Sheridan is all-in on valorizing the petro economy. It speaks to how muddled, perhaps deliberately, his politics are that he can have the entire Dutton franchise be about preserving and respecting the land (and demonizing miners at multiple turns) and then make a show with basically the theme “fuck the environment.” It's also just incredibly wasteful when it comes to its cast: That's what you do with Jon Hamm? Slap a carbon tax on this one. By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Benedict Cumberbatch Hoping To Adapt Classic British Novel ‘Rogue Male' Next Year
Source: deadline.com    Published: 2025-11-27 18:06:00

By Jake Kanter International Investigations Editor Benedict Cumberbatch has confirmed that he remains committed to adapting Rogue Male, the classic British novel that he says inspired Ian Fleming to write James Bond. Cumberbatch and his production company SunnyMarch announced in 2016 that they planned to adapt Geoffrey Household's book, but the feature film has yet to get off the ground. Speaking on the SmartLess podcast, hosted by Sean Hayes, Jason Bateman, and Will Arnett, Cumberbatch said he hoped to slate the shoot for 2026. He warned, however, that “there are other huge commitments involving cloaks floating about,” which appeared to be confirmation that he is reprising his role as Doctor Strange in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Related Stories News Miles Teller Blames "One Really Important Person" On 'Fantastic Four' For "F***ing It All Up" News Elizabeth Olsen Says She's "Excited To See" Marvel's 'VisionQuest': "It Really Sounds Like A Trifecta" “We haven't got a filming date yet, but it's something we're trying to slate for next year,” Cumberbatch said. “We will make it, definitely.” Watch on Deadline Published in 1939, Rogue Male follows an unnamed English sportsman who attempts to assassinate a European dictator, strongly implied to be Adolf Hitler. He is caught, tortured and left for dead, but escapes back to England, where he hides out in the countryside with enemy agents and police in pursuit. “It's the original fugitive novel and a huge inspiration for Ian Fleming for Bond,” Cumberbatch continued. “When we first sat down to talk about this, [we thought] is this a bit of a guy's film? “The longer we were exploring the themes of it and the motivation behind the guy's actions, and the outcome, and how he's turned on by his own side, as well as the side he's tried to take down, it's fascinating how it plays into the political spectrum of what's going on in the world right now.” When the project was first announced, Michael Lesslie (Macbeth, Assassin's Creed) was hired to write the screenplay. It was set up at Fox Searchlight, and Cumberbatch was slated to star. Peter O'Toole appeared in a BBC adaptation of Rogue Male made for television in 1977. Twentieth Century Fox adapted the novel in 1940 as Man Hunt. Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Comments On Deadline Hollywood are monitored. So don't go off topic, don't impersonate anyone, and don't get your facts wrong. The Hard Choices Public Media Institutions Are Facing Every Single Day
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-11-27 17:00:00

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. Recently, I was compelled to do a hard thing: I turned down a grant. The decision was painful because, right now, the organization I lead — Black Public Media — really needs funding. Congress' rescission of $1.1 billion in public media support stripped $1.8 million of committed funding from our budget. Like many others in the public media sector, and the greater arts community, my team and I are now scrambling to accelerate our fundraising efforts. To stay afloat, we've had to do other hard things: trim staff, decrease grant-making, and cut programs. Fortunately, BPM also has private sector support, so we're not closing our doors. Some of our donors are stepping up in remarkable ways, but in today's anti-DEI climate, others are choosing to lie low. As grateful as we are for the help we received, it is unclear whether private philanthropy alone can fill the $1.8 million gap. For nearly 50 years, BPM has helped independent media makers bring stories about the global Black experience to the public. We've long served as a vital funding source for content creators whose projects make other funders uneasy. “Hip Hop: Beyond Beats & Rhymes,” “I Am Not Your Negro,” “Red Summers VR,” and “Mama Gloria” are among the hundreds of projects we've supported. Projects we fund sometimes provide source material for narrative films, video games and XR experiences, reaching even broader audiences. BPM's collaborations with PBS bring groundbreaking broadcasts, streaming projects, and community engagement initiatives to the public free of charge. These projects often do the difficult but necessary job of challenging norms and sparking lively, essential conversations. Pursuing BPM's mission has never been easy, but lately it has become especially fraught. The $35K NEA grant we walked away from was modest, but it would have supported our community screenings program. I made the difficult decision to decline the funding to safeguard BPM's independence. If we accepted the grant, I worried we'd end up clashing with the federal agency over films that don't conform with the current administration's priorities. Earlier this year, we were advised to avoid using words included on the government's growing list of disfavored words. The so-called “woke” terms include: diversity, inclusion, climate crisis, equity, systemic, racism, LGBTQ, social justice, minority-serving institution, pronouns, and Black, the first word in our name! The makers we serve frequently pursue stories addressing the themes on this list. Avoiding those words to placate a funder would compromise our very mission — one hard thing we just won't do. Independent media makers are experiencing hardships, too. The fact that so many are small business owners and job creators in communities across the United States — and that public funding is a force multiplier in stimulating local economies — is too often missed in this discussion. Related Stories Two Weeks on ‘Eyes Wide Shut' Turned Into Four Years: Shooting Second Unit for Stanley Kubrick ‘Stranger Things' Season 5 Leaves You Wanting Less Earlier this year, the National Science Foundation abruptly terminated parts of a $3.2 million grant it had awarded to a Scientists in the Family project, which includes a documentary titled, “My Mom the Scientist.” The award-winning filmmaker, Thomas Allen Harris, has over 30 years of experience in the industry. The film is about his mother's perseverance in a field that didn't openly welcome people who looked like her. This financial setback affects not only Harris, but ripples through to hurt all the subcontractors he would have supported and the engagement activities that would have highlighted other Black scientists in local communities. Globally, the $13.64 billion documentary film and television industry creates jobs and benefits a wide range of small businesses. Firms that provide equipment, editing services, graphic design, AV, lighting, catering, costuming, transportation, marketing, publicity — the list goes on. Our sister organizations that support stories from the Asian American, Latinx, Native American, Pacific Islander, and other underrepresented communities face similar challenges. The artists we all work with create content reflecting the rich diversity of this nation. We're certainly not the only members of the creative economy going through hard times. But as public media producers and distributors, our artists' work is accessible in all corners of the nation, at no expense to viewers. It contributes to the cultural enrichment and connectedness of all Americans on a scale unparalleled by most other art forms. That's something to be cherished, not dismissed. The United States is at its best and most prosperous when creative freedom rings, knowledge is shared and intolerance finds no shelter. Preserving these ideals requires more of us to be willing to do the hard things. Leslie Fields-Cruz is the executive director of Black Public Media, the nation's only nonprofit solely dedicated to the development of nonfiction Black content for distribution on public media. Fields-Cruz joined BPM in 2001 to manage its program development fund. She served as director of programs from 2005-2008 and as VP of programs and operations from 2008-2014 before being named BPM's third executive director in 2014. ‘SNL's Marcello Hernández & ‘Superman's Skyler Gisondo Join ‘Shrek 5' As Shrek & Fiona's Sons
Source: deadline.com    Published: 2025-11-27 16:08:00

By Anthony D'Alessandro Editorial Director/Box Office Editor Some special news this Thanksgiving morning and that's that Saturday Night Live‘s Marcello Hernández and Superman‘s Skyler Gisondo have joined the voice cast of Shrek 5 as Shrek and Fiona's sons, Fergus and Farkle. They join the franchise cast of Mike Myers, Eddie Murphy, Cameron Diaz, who are back in their respective roles as Shrek, Donkey and Fiona. Zendaya is also in on the fun as Shrek and Fiona's daughter, Felicia. The animated movie from DreamWorks Animation and Universal hits theaters on June 30, 2027. Related Stories Casting Kenneth Branagh To Voice 'Goblin', David Mikalson's A24 Hybrid Film; Skyler Gisondo Circling Late Night TV Bowen Yang Present On Sabrina Carpenter-Hosted 'SNL' Despite Missing Live Taping Shrek 5 is directed by Shrek franchise veterans Conrad Vernon and Walt Dohrn. Vernon's directing credits include Shrek 2, Madagascar 2 and is the voice of Gingerbread Man (aka Gingy). Dohrn (Trolls films) worked on the second and third Shrek films as a writer and artist and as Head of Story on the fourth film. Dohrn also voiced the character of Rumpelstilskin in Shrek Forever After. Watch on Deadline Pic will be produced by returning producer Gina Shay (Trolls films), who produced Shrek Forever After and by Illumination CEO and Academy Award® nominee Chris Meledandri (Despicable Me and Minions franchise, The Super Mario Bros. Movie, Sing and Secret Life of Pets films). The film will be co-directed by Brad Ableson (Minions: The Rise of Gru, The Simpsons). The four Shrek movies have minted close to $3 billion around the world, with the first movie in 2001 winning the first ever Oscar for an Animated Feature. The movie spawned a global live-touring show, an award-winning Broadway musical that earned eight Tony nominations and 12 Drama Desk nominations, plus an immersive, top-tourist destination in London and a popular events and attractions across Universal Studios Parks worldwide. Hernández is represented by CAA, LBI Entertainment and Patti Felkner. Gisondo is represented by UTA, Untitled Entertainment and Jackoway Tyerman. Hallmark's Ben Rosenbaum Dropped a Big Hint Before Wife Erin Krakow's Pregnancy Reveal (EXCLUSIVE)
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-11-27 16:00:26

Days before real-life Hallmark couple Erin Krakow and Ben Rosenbaum revealed they're expecting their first baby — thrilling “When Calls The Heart” fans with the news on November 26, 2025 — Rosenbaum gave EntertainmentNow a little glimpse into their private life. His comments, it turns out, included a sweet hint that he and Krakow, who've been married since June, have been focused on their newest roles as parents-to-be since wrapping filming on season 13. Rosenbaum, who stars in Hallmark Channel's Thanksgiving weekend premiere of “The Christmas Cup,” had to reschedule his initial interview with EntertainmentNow about the upcoming movie because he was stuck at an appointment. No big deal, of course — but now it's clear the dad-to-be has likely been to quite a few appointments lately, evidenced in part by the adorable pics Krakow posted of them with their dog, Willoughby, while holding up sonogram images to reveal their baby news. Rosenbaum also mentioned that they'd been catching up on doctor's appointments when he did sit down with EntertainmentNow, noting that since “When Calls the Heart” recently wrapped filming in Vancouver, he and Krakow have been settling back into “boring life stuff” at home in Los Angeles. “We do try to maintain some privacy away from set,” Rosenbaum said. “But in general, I can say we go from filming ‘When Calls the Heart,' where we're very focused; our attention is on work when we're up there, we know what our job is to do, and it demands a lot of time, especially for Erin. So our hiatus time is really the time that we get to, like, relax.” “And also, unfortunately, it gets pretty busy pretty quick,” he continued. “But with all good things, you know — travel, visit and see family, and then just the boring life stuff of, like, all the things that we've neglected while we've been up in Canada. We have to come back to L.A. and kind of pay attention to things around the house and doctor's appointments, and all that kind of stuff. It's just kind of back to normal life, plus the fun of travel.” Krakow, who plays WCTH lead Elizabeth Thornton, and Rosenbaum, who plays Mike Hickam on the show, have both been on the series since its start in 2014. But the couple met in 2009 when they were both cast in “The Importance of Being Earnest” at the renowned Guthrie Theater in Rosenbaum's hometown of Minneapolis, he told EntertainmentNow. “Honestly, when Erin and I first met, I actually saw her working the first time we met, and really just developed a crush on her talent,” Rosenbaum said. “She's just so good on stage and on screen.” The two were able to spend time together in her native New York when a touring stage production he was in opened and closed there, he said, noting that gave them “more opportunities to connect, and a romance developed from there.” Rosenbaum and Krakow kept their romance quiet for years, but they began hinting at their relationship in social media photos several years ago, including taking trips with fellow “When Calls The Heart” couple Kevin McGarry and Kayla Wallace (who are also expecting their first baby) and adopting their dog Willoughby. They surprised fans by posting wedding photos on June 23 and have shocked Hearties once again with their baby news five months later. As Rosenbaum prepares for the premiere of his first starring role in a Hallmark movie — another big achievement in 2025 — he told EntertainmentNow that his wife is his “biggest cheerleader.” Season 13 of “When Calls The Heart” is set to premiere on January 4, while “The Christmas Cup” starring Rosenbaum, Rhiannon Fish, and several WCTH castmates premieres on November 30 at 6 p.m. Eastern time. 'South Park' Takes on Pete Hegseth's Department of War in New Thanksgiving-Themed Episode
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-11-27 15:54:21

By Jeff Ihaza Among the many members of this Trump Administration to be spoofed on this season of South Park — easily one of the wildest yet — Secretary of War Pete Hegseth has so far been spared. That is, until last night. During a Thanksgiving-themed episode titled “Turkey Trot,” Hegseth, a former Fox News anchor and military general, was depicted as an Instagram Reels-obsessed content creator sent to town on Trump's orders to free Peter Thiel, who you might recall was arrested in the previous episode. “Don't just make a bunch of content. Like, actually go and do something,” South Park's Trump tells Hegseth. Elsewhere, the town is planning to host a 5k Turkey Trot that is, naturally, sponsored by Saudi Arabia. The only caveat? Contestants can't speak ill of the royal family. Cartman recruits Token to his team in hopes of winning the $5,000 prize. In a send-up of the increasingly prevalent ideas of race science permeating through conservative circles, Cartman describes himself as a “racing scientist,” noting that Token's race always wins races. Trending Stories Jackson Browne's Son Ethan Dead at 52 Judge Plans to Force Sale of Nicki Minaj's $20 Million Mansion to Pay Security Guard's Judgment How a Mac-and-Cheese Recipe Turned Chef Tini Into TikTok's Thanksgiving Queen Katy Perry Poised to Recover $1.8 Million in Wild Montecito Mansion War The stage is thus set for an Eddington-style standoff, as Hegseth arrives in South Park and immediately mistakes the race for an Antifa uprising. The quick-thinking Secretary of War immediately starts live-streaming the event before being accosted by Director of Homeland Security Kristi Noem, who ends up shooting a dog in a scenario seemingly plucked from Noem's memoir, which caused a stir during the 2024 election. The episode ends with Hegseth botching the Peter Thiel extraction and ending up in jail himself right alongside Thiel. Popular on Rolling Stone This latest season of South Park has consistently raised eyebrows as it takes on the current administration's key figures head-on. All the while, they've battled their network, Paramount+, which recently completed a merger with David Ellison's Skydance in a deal that many believe came with political assurances to the current administration. For more than twenty years, South Park has made skewering pop culture its defining ethos. Co-creator Trey Parker recently told the New York Times that “It's not that we got all political, it's that politics became pop culture.” We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Bindi Irwin Celebrates Brother Robert's DWTS Victory a Decade After Her Own Mirrorball Win
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-11-27 15:30:47

It turned out to be a historic night for the Irwins! Fan-favorite Robert Irwin has officially won “Dancing with the Stars.” His sister Bindi Irwin marked the milestone with a loving message and a celebratory photo. “TWO MIRRORBALLS NOW CALL AUSTRALIA ZOO HOME!!!! Congratulations and all the love in the world to @robertirwinphotography and @witneycarson. What. A. Night,” she wrote. The win arrives ten years after Bindi earned her own historic Mirrorball trophy during season 21 with Derek Hough. Now, Robert has added a second shining prize to the family's legacy. The siblings each made “DWTS” history in their own way, drawing global love as they honored their late father, Steve Irwin, through their performances. Robert's victory capped a heated three-round, three-hour live finale in Los Angeles on Tuesday evening. The 21-year-old overcame a painful rib injury to defeat fellow finalists Jordan Chiles, Alix Earle, Dylan Efron, and Elaine Hendrix. His emotional season, which began with a visit to his father's star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in August, made him a fan favorite from the start. The unexpected elimination of frontrunner Whitney Leavitt the week before pushed the momentum even further in Robert's direction. By the final night, his win felt inevitable. Robert delivered some of his best dances of the season during the finale. His judges' choice quickstep to “Are You Gonna Be My Girl” by Jet showed clean footwork and a strong frame. His freestyle, performed to Avicii's “The Nights” and Sam Sparro's “Black & Gold,” leaned into full-throttle choreography and explosive lifts. He also excelled in the “instant dance challenge,” where he and partner Witney Carson received their style and song only minutes before performing. Despite entering the show with no dance background, Robert leaned into his natural charisma and physicality. He embraced the lighthearted moments, including ripping his shirt mid-salsa, while still honoring his family values and his father's legacy. After taking the Mirrorball trophy, Robert said he is heading into an even busier chapter of life. “I go to New York and then straight to South Africa to film another show over there,” he told E! News. “And then, I'm back home.” Witney chimed in that she will be with him soon. “Witney's coming down to Australia,” Robert said, as the dancer joked, “You're not getting rid of me that easy.” Robert reflected on the meaning of the season. “I've been able to write my own legacy with Witney as we tell stories of positivity, vulnerability, passion and fun.” He also shared that this journey has been years in the making. A recently resurfaced 2015 video showed young Robert backstage during Bindi's winning season, saying he hoped to compete on the show someday. That dream just came true—along with a family celebration that now includes two Mirrorball trophies at Australia Zoo. Xochitl Gomez claims she's 'single' — but fuels Robert Irwin dating speculation with pointed social media move
Source: Page Six    Published: 2025-11-27 14:22:00

Xochitl Gomez claims she's “single” — but fueled speculation she's dating Robert Irwin with a pointed social media move. During Tuesday night's finale of “Dancing With the Stars” Season 34, which saw Irwin win the dance competition, Gomez, who won Season 32, was asked in an interview with “DWTS” pro Jan Ravnik whether she's “single.” Giggling, the actress insisted, “Yes, I am. I am. Yes, I am.” Advertisement Advertisement However, on Wednesday, she took to Instagram to post a carousel from finale night. “What a season! Congratulations to all the finalists ♥️🪩🫂,” Gomez, 19, captioned the photos, which included a cozy close-up shot with Irwin, 21. Gomez concluded her slideshow with a picture of a much-younger Irwin holding the Len Goodman Mirrorball Trophy his older sister, Bindi Irwin, won in 2015's “DWTS” Season 21. “The last picture though,” he commented. Advertisement Robert, for his part, hasn't done much to dispel the romance rumors, which sparked after he and Gomez displayed undeniable chemistry while performing on “DWTS” together earlier this month. (The show's current contestants were paired with past champions for a dance relay.) “Everyone's asking if you and Xochitl are an item!” a TMZ paparazzo said to Robert as he arrived for practice. Advertisement Swerving the question, the wildlife conservationist replied, “Oh, my gosh. We had the best time! That dance was so much fun.” Sign up for Virtual Reali-Tea with Danny and Evan, our must-read newsletter! Please provide a valid email. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Want more celebrity and pop culture news? He marveled at the energetic routine, going on to gush that “she's the best.” Asked once again whether the pair are “an item or just friends,” Robert smiled and walked into the studio. Then ahead of Tuesday's show, Gomez was photographed paying the zookeeper a private visit outside his trailer. Advertisement The “Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness” star presented Robert with a massive bouquet of flowers, gave him an affectionate side hug and laughed as she chatted with him. Advertisement After the seemingly flirty exchange, a source told Page Six that the duo have been enjoying each other's company since connecting through the dance competition. “They are having a lot of fun. They're both extroverts with a lot of energy,” the source said, calling Gomez “the sweetest person.”

Brian Eno, Neneh Cherry, and More Unite for Palestine Benefit Single
Source: Pitchfork    Published: 2025-11-27 13:58:44

Together for Palestine, the humanitarian operation that put on a massive benefit concert in September, has announced a benefit single featuring Brian Eno, Neneh Cherry, and many more. “Lullaby,” a version of the traditional Palestinian song “Yamma Mweel El Hawa,” will be released on December 12, with designs on the coveted UK Christmas No. 1 slot. Others in the ensemble include Nadine Shah, Mabel, Celeste, and Bastille's Dan Smith. Peter Gabriel wrote an English-language lyric for the cover, and the Palestinian musician Nai Barghouti arranged and recomposed the song alongside Shards' Kieran Brunt. Eno said in a press release, “After a year defined by unimaginable loss, grief and injustice, we want to end with an act of love for Palestine's children. Lullaby reflects their beauty, their longing and their hope. If we rally together and download it, we have a real shot at landing Christmas No. 1—and turning that moment into vital life-saving support for Gaza's families.” Barghouti adds, “This lullaby from our Palestinian musical heritage has been with me since early childhood. Today, it returns at a much-needed time as a reminder of what Palestinians will never lose: hope, defiance, beauty, and dignity.” Kieran Brunt co-produced “Lullaby” alongside Benji B and Henri Davies. Also featured on the track are Amena, Lana Lubany, Leigh-Anne, London Community Gospel Choir, Sura Abdo, Tyson, Yasmeen Ayyashi, and Ysee. Together for Palestine's T4P label will release the song, via distributor Empire. All proceeds go to Choose Love's Together for Palestine Fund, which supports the Palestinian-led organisations Taawon, Palestine Children's Relief Fund and Palestine Medical Relief Service. In Los Angeles, meanwhile, another benefit concert, Artists for Aid, has been detailed ahead of its January 10 staging. Organized for the second year by Mustafa, the concert will feature Geese, Blood Orange, Alex G, Clairo, Faye Webster, Noname, Ravyn Lenae, Daniel Cesar, and more, with hosts Bella Hadid and Pedro Pascal. A new batch of artists has also signed up to geoblock their music from streaming in Israel. My Bloody Valentine, Saba, Shygirl, YHWH Nailgun, and Denzel Curry are among the additions to No Music for Genocide. © 2025 Condé Nast. All rights reserved. Kevin Spacey Set To Face Civil Sex Assault Claims In London Court
Source: deadline.com    Published: 2025-11-27 11:10:00

By Zac Ntim International Reporter Kevin Spacey will face civil claims of sexual assault from three men at the High Court in London next October. A British performer named Ruari Cannon, who has waived his right to anonymity, and two other claimants who have not, have alleged Spacey abused them between 2000 and 2015. A judge set the provisional trial date of 12 October 2026 for the cases at a hearing earlier this week. Spacey denies all the allegations. Spacey was cleared of nine sexual offence charges at a criminal trial in 2023. He was also found not liable in a U.S. civil case brought by actor Anthony Rapp, who alleged Spacey molested him when he was 14. Related Stories News Kevin Spacey Clarifies Comments About Having "No Home," Living In Hotels & Airbnbs While Working As A Lounge Singer In Cyprus News Under-The-Radar Kevin Spacey Sci-Fi Thriller 'The Tenth Planet' On Sale At AFM With 'The King's Speech' Exec Mark Foligno Producing Spacey made headlines last week with an interview with The Telegraph newspaper during which he described his financial situation as “not great,” adding, “I'm living in hotels, I'm living in Airbnbs, I'm going where the work is. I literally have no home, that's what I'm attempting to explain.” Watch on Deadline In a social post a few days later, Spacey expanded on his comments from The Telegraph interview and explained that he was not homeless in the literal sense. In gratitude 🙏🏼 pic.twitter.com/P0zcxCo0gk The House of Cards alum, who last year appeared on Piers Morgan Uncensored to discuss his debts, including the foreclosure of his Baltimore abode, said, “The costs over these last seven years have been astronomical. I've had very little coming in and everything going out.” Spacey likened his predicament to the experiences of actors of yore, who were swept into the Hollywood blacklist as a result of McCarthyism. He cited Kirk Douglas' willingness to work with screenwriter Dalton Trumbo, then blacklisted, as the type of strategic allyship that could help him right the ship. “So, my feeling is if Martin Scorsese or Quentin Tarantino call Evan [Lowenstein, Spacey's manager] tomorrow, it will be over,” he posited. “I will be incredibly honored and delighted when that level of talent picks up the phone. And I believe it's going to happen.” Most recently, Spacey wrapped production in the U.K. on an under-the-radar sci-fi thriller called The Tenth Planet. The project was on sale at this year's American Film Market. Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Comments On Deadline Hollywood are monitored. Taylor Swift & Travis Kelce Eye Major Change to Wedding Plans: Report
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-11-27 10:49:54

Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce may be reconsidering a key detail in their upcoming wedding. On Wednesday, Page Six reported that the couple is considering a change to their original wedding venue due to a potentially larger guest list than they initially planned. Sources claimed Swift and Kelce are reviewing the list and may want to invite more people. The outlet added that Kelce maintains strong ties with many of his childhood friends from Cleveland, Ohio, in addition to having a wide circle of teammates and NFL acquaintances. Swift, on the other hand, has a plethora of music industry friends she is considering for her guest list. Previously, it was reported that Swift and Kelce plan to host an intimate wedding in Rhode Island next summer. According to The US Sun, the “Cruel Summer” singer and the NFL star are prepared to drop $1.2 million into the landscaping alone in Swift's $32 million pad for the big day. But a new report from Page Six claimed that Swift and Kelce are contemplating keeping the Rhode Island plans and might host a second wedding venue elsewhere. Sources told the outlet that the couple is eyeing the Ocean House Hotel in Watch Hill, which is located right next to Swift's estate. Page Six further reported that Swift and Kelce could scrap their original plan and go “all out” at a larger venue. Among the potential locations is Blackberry Farm, a 4,200-acre luxury resort in Tennessee. The outlet added that Swift and Kelce are also exploring the idea of a destination wedding abroad, with options including private islands like Necker in the British Virgin Islands or elsewhere in the Caribbean. Reps for Swift and Kelce have yet to confirm these reports. Earlier this month, rumors swirled that Taylor Swift is lining up a star-studded squad of A-list bridesmaids for her wedding. According to a report by The US Sun, the mega-pop star already asked her longtime friend, Gigi Hadid, to be part of the bridal party. The outlet claimed that the supermodel was “thrilled” and “wasn't expecting” to be asked and accepted immediately. In addition to Hadid, Swift reportedly asked her fellow pop star Selena Gomez to be one of her bridesmaids. The outlet noted that the “Opalite” singer hopes to get advice from Gomez, who married Benny Blanco earlier this year. Franz Ferdinand's Alex Kapronos Once Got a ‘Bizarre' Tweet From Donald Trump
Source: Billboard    Published: 2025-11-27 10:26:51

The band wrote the 2016 track "Demagogue" when Trump was still a candidate for the presidential election. By Lars Brandle Franz Ferdinand and Donald Trump share almost nothing in common, apart from their Scottish heritage, and an unexpected interaction on social media. The alternative rock outfit is currently in Australia for a national tour, kicking Wednesday, Nov. 26 at Red Hill Auditorium in Perth, Western Australia, and visiting Brisbane, Thirroul and Melbourne, before wrapping up in Sydney. As the “Take Me Out” singers bang the drum for those dates, frontman Alex Kapronos stopped by Triple M for a chat with WA-based breakfast show hosts Robbie & Carly. Related 'KPop Demon Hunters' Songs Rule Top Movie Songs Chart for Fourth Month Here's Why Tems Says She Won't Return to Uganda Any Time Soon Sabrina Carpenter's 'Manchild' No. 1 on Top TV Songs Chart Via 'Nobody Wants This' Explore Franz Ferdinand See latest videos, charts and news See latest videos, charts and news Conversation, naturally, turned to the weather — where the band has come from, and the blazing heat they've arrived in — and the political climate. The band penned the 2016 track “Demagogue” when Trump was still a candidate for the presidential election, which he went on to win, against most political observers' predictions. With “Demagogue,” Franz Ferdinand proved once more that Scots don't mince their words. “From the wall straight to la cuenta/Those pussy grabbing fingers won't let go of me now,” the sing early on. And later, “From the mob to chapter eleven/Those tiny vulgar fingers on the nuclear bomb.” When asked the band had heard from Trump's camp, Kapronos quipped: “He's a sensitive chap, isn't he? When we wrote that song, he was only just going forward as a candidate. We were writing from the perspective of, ‘Oh God, imagine if…' And here we are… we don't need to imagine anymore.” Kapronos “didn't hear anything back from him personally, although years ago he replied to a tweet of mine, which was bizarre,” he reveals. Also, one of Trump's daughters “crashed backstage at one of our shows back in 2004,” he recounts. “It was like, ‘Who's this woman in our dressing room?'” The band has begun their tour down under at the best possible time. “We left a very rainy, cold, dark Europe to come to a beautiful springtime Australia — and you feel that energy,” Kapronos remarks. “It lifts you up. Even if you're hungover or jet-lagged, the energy of the crowd is transformative.” Also, Kapranos notes, the group's Perth show will something of a family affair. “My sister's husband is a Perth boy, so we know quite a few folk here. I think we've got a guest list of 60! Perth feels like nowhere else on earth: the trees, the plants, the wildlife, it's so unique.” Formed in Glasgow in 2002, Franz Ferdinand has landed seven U.K. top 10 albums, including a No. 1 with 2005's You Could Have It So Much Better, and scooped best British group and best rock act at the BRIT Award in the same year. Their U.S. chart story includes two hits on the Billboard Hot 100, and five appearances on the Billboard 200, including two top 10s. Stream the Triple M interview here. Get weekly rundowns straight to your inbox A daily briefing on what matters in the music industry Send us a tip using our anonymous form. A daily briefing on what matters in the music industry Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Billboard is a part of Penske Media Corporation. © 2025 Billboard Media, LLC. All Rights Reserved.

South Park clearly thankful it can drill into some of this Saudi Arabia stuff
Source: AV Club    Published: 2025-11-27 06:47:00

Never let it be said that South Park isn't grateful for its ability to be a lot more timely than almost any other animated show on television, allowing the Comedy Central series to tackle almost any aspect of our modern political and social clusterfuck (that isn't the influence of any billionaires who might be personal friends with Trey Parker and Matt Stone, anyway). Certainly, no other cartoon on TV has now dived in more gleefully in tackling recent criticisms of American athletes and artists taking money from the government of Saudi Arabia, as the series did with its pre-Thanksgiving installment, “Turkey Trot.” The episode—reportedly the penultimate episode of South Park‘s bizarrely truncated 28th season—dealt with a bunch of the usual suspects, lightly touching on the show's ongoing Trump plotline (albeit without going to the graphic lengths it recently achieved), and allowing Eric Cartman to once again be a force of town-wide menace. (In this case, getting obsessed with “race science,” which involves him recruiting South Park's one Black kid onto his team to try to win the titular event.) Oh, and it got some swipes at Pete Hesgeth in there, but Hesgeth is so obviously buffoonish that even the series seems to realize that clowning on him—by depicting him as a rampant attention seeker in a fight with Kristi Noem to see who can milk more attention out of any given situation—is at least a little bit redundant. As it usually has over the last few months, South Park reserved its actual satire for chunkier material, in this case the controversy surrounding the recent Riyadh Comedy Festival, and some of the comedians who participated in it. To some extent, the show drew from an older playbook, doing a bit of the old “both sides” maneuver: Having usual moral voice Token repeatedly try to drop out of the town's Saudi-backed Turkey Trot over the queasy feelings associated with taking Saudi money, only to have Cartman point out that ostracized regimes rarely improve on topics like human rights abuses. Or, to put it in the show's terms, asking if he wouldn't prefer “them to pay America for sports rather than hacking up reporters and paying Pete Davidson to do comedy?” (Kevin Hart also took a similar hit.) Putting the words in Cartman's mouth certainly suggests that the series is ascribing cynical motivations somewhere, but it still makes South Park one of the only mainstream American TV shows—outside of, like the news, and the late-night programs—that's directly addressing the controversy. André Holland, Zazie Beetz, Kate Mara's ‘The Dutchman' Sets Early 2026 Release (Exclusive)
Source: The Hollywood Reporter    Published: 2025-11-27 06:01:08

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Director Andre Gaines' feature adaptation of the Obie Award-winning play will hit theaters from Rogue Pictures and Inaugural Entertainment after premiering at SXSW. By Ryan Gajewski Senior Entertainment Reporter The Dutchman is ready to arrive in theaters. Rogue Pictures and Inaugural Entertainment are set to release director Andre Gaines' psychological thriller in theaters nationwide Jan. 2, 2026, The Hollywood Reporter has exclusively learned. André Holland, Zazie Beetz and Kate Mara star in the modern feature adaptation of the 1964 Obie Award-winning play of the same name. The Dutchman centers on Clay (Holland), a successful but troubled businessman who attends therapy sessions with wife Kaya (Beetz) but soon learns that the therapist follows unconventional methods. Clay also deals with the potentially life-altering impact of a chance encounter with seductive Lula (Mara), whom he meets on a New York City subway ride. Related Video Related Stories General News Ben & Jerry's Co-Founder Ben Cohen Among Wide-Ranging SXSW London 2026 Speaker Lineup Movies Benjamin Flaherty's Feature Doc 'Shuffle,' a SXSW Grand Jury Winner, Debuts Theatrical Trailer Gaines helmed the movie from a script he co-wrote with Qasim Basir that is based on Amiri Baraka's play Dutchman. Gaines produces the project alongside Jonathan T. Baker. Stephen McKinley Henderson, Aldis Hodge, Lauren E. Banks and Lenny Platt round out the cast for the film that premiered earlier this year at SXSW. “The Dutchman is a bold, electrifying adaptation that captures the raw power of Amiri Baraka's play with unflinching style and urgency — exactly the kind of provocative, conversation-starting cinema that audiences are starving for right now,” says Inaugural Entertainment founder Kevin Weisberg. “For Inaugural Entertainment it is the exact type of film we can't wait to put in theater.” Adds Gaines, “Rogue and Inaugural are the perfect partners to bring The Dutchman to audiences across the country. Marc [Danon], Mike [Arrieta], Kevin and Ryan [Adams] have been champions of this film since day one, which means the world to me. Bringing The Dutchman to theaters nationwide is not just a dream come true — it's an opportunity for audiences to engage with a story that demands to be felt, enjoyed and discussed.” In her review of The Dutchman for The Hollywood Reporter, critic Lovia Gyarkye wrote that Gaines “intensifies the dramatic work's surrealist undertones and takes the central couple's story above ground.” Gyarkye added that moving the narrative beyond the play's train car gives the film “greater contemporary resonance.” Sign up for THR news straight to your inbox every day Send us a tip using our anonymous form.

‘Stranger Things' Star Millie Bobby Brown On Working With David Harbour In Their Season 5 Scenes: “It Makes Me Want To Bring My A Game”
Source: deadline.com    Published: 2025-11-27 06:00:00

By Dessi Gomez SEO Staff Writer SPOILER ALERT: This post spoils Volume 1 of Stranger Things Season 5 – the entire first four episodes. Father and daughter duo Jim Hopper (David Harbour) and Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown) are back in action in the fifth and final season of Stranger Things. Following behind-the-scenes rumors of tension between the costars with a reported harassment and bullying complaint filed against Harbour by Brown, the actress reflected on her working relationship with Harbour given that most of her scenes in the first four episodes of Stranger Things Season 5 Volume 1 take place with him in The Upside Down. “David and I have a great relationship. We work really closely together in the scenes and in preparing for the scenes. I really am excited for everyone to see the labor of love and hard work we've put into the closure of our relationship and what that looks like and to give some of the fans,” she told Deadline. “Especially the Hopper and Eleven fans. Those scenes that I feel, I think, are going to be quite impactful. I love it. It makes me want to bring my A game every single time I see that I'm on the call sheet working with him because I know he's bringing it right back.” Watch on Deadline Brown affirmed that she felt safe going to emotional depths with Harbour when Eleven is compromised by what they call “kryptonite” or the satellite technology that paralyzes her and renders her powers useless. “Of course, I felt safe. We've worked together for 10 years. I feel safe with everyone on that set. Naturally [we]'ve been doing it for so long,” she said. “We also play father and daughter, so naturally you have a closer bond than the rest because we have had some really intense scenes together, especially in Season 2.” RELATED: ‘Stranger Things 5': Jamie Campbell Bower Unpacks Vecna Kidnapping [SPOILER] In Vol. 1 & The “Vexation” Of Knowing [SPOILER] Might've Found The Monster's Weakness Season 2 watched the start of Hopper and El's relationship when he took her in after she disappeared saving the four boys from a Demogorgon in the Season 1 finale. At one point, Eleven compared Hop to Dr. Brenner, who she calls Papa, because he wouldn't let her leave his cabin, and the scene is known to be a heated one. “It's definitely sometimes a wake up call because it's a year-long filming, so every scene you go, ‘Okay, am I gonna give it 150% today? Because I have this huge scene tomorrow.' And you have to be honest with yourself,” Brown said. “I would have been exhausted. It's very taxing. So you really have to choose the moments that you are going to lock in and the moments that you go, ‘Okay. This is more emotional today. This is more expositional today.' You have to map it out, and I do physically. I highlight my pages by color, with emotion, and also weekdays and that helps me plan out what my week looks like and what kind of emotions I have to harness.” In addition to mentally emotional scenes, Brown also has some very involved stunts because Eleven has leveled up her powers. RELATED: ‘Stranger Things' Stars Noah Schnapp & Millie Bobby Brown On Revisiting Their Season 1 Performances For The De-Aging Process In Later Episodes “I love stunts. I love that element of El. I can't lie. It taught me a lot about stamina. It just helped me train entirely with stamina. Doing that for 13 hours a day outside when it's cold, your body doesn't know it's acting,” she said. “Your body does physically think it's being thrown in the air. Your body does think it's going through something traumatic. So it's it's kind of connecting your mind, body and spirit, and really locking in to that.” “I can be thrown in the air, [but] if my face isn't doing the thing I need it to, then it doesn't work. But then also ‘Okay, you throw your left hand behind the wire. You're entirely twisted in the whole take is off,” Brown continued. “It's like riding a horse. The horse knows exactly what the human is doing on top of the horse, they can feel every single limb. So you have to lock in to yourself and stay in tune with yourself. And that, I have never done more in my work, so this season, I think I've threw myself into that quite heavily.” Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy.
